Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Identity Work, Stigma, and Status among Wounded Warriors

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Increased public attention on wounded and injured veterans of the Iraq and Afghanistan wars has popularized the term "wounded warrior." Wounded warrior is a new and symbolic phrase that parallels a shift in the larger social context for post-9/11 wounded veterans. In this dissertation, This research examines the symbolic meaning of "wounded warrior" and how this construct creates social expectations that impact the community and everyday lives of wounded post-9/11 veterans. Using in-depth interviews with 40 post-9/11 wounded/injured/ill veterans in combination with a content analysis of the mainstream media coverage of wounded veterans over the past decade, this project analyzes how the wounded warrior context shapes the social relationships, identity, and structural resources for the newest generation of wounded veterans. Because of the increased recognition of invisible injuries such as Traumatic Brain Injury (TBI) and Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD), this research uses the visibility of one?s injuries (whether they are seen or not and the nature of the injury) as a comparative focal point for analyzing the convergence and divergence of the portrayal and personal experiences of veterans within the wounded warrior construct.

The wounded warrior construct provides a theoretically unique opportunity to examine interactions among stigma, identity, and status. How veterans enact their identity and role as a wounded veteran also illuminates how veterans' status as a wounded warrior can counteract the stigma from their service-connected injuries/disabilities/illnesses. Using qualitative data from in-depth interviews with post-9/11 wounded veterans and a content analysis of recent media coverage, this study addresses three specific interactions among stigma, identity work and visibility: (1) how and when the potential stigma of an individual veteran's injuries is counteracted by their status as a wounded warrior, (2) how this affects the management of their identity through identity work, and (3) how individuals with different visible and less visible injuries negotiate within the same identity framework and expectations of being a wounded warrior. The complex range of injuries and whether those injuries align with stereotypical images of a "wounded warrior" changes veterans? ability to offset stigma, bringing into question how, when, and under what circumstances this stigma offsetting process occurs. Completed interviews highlight how veterans? identity work as a wounded warrior is influenced by public perceptions of wounded veterans and point to differences in the experience of stigma by context, such as visibility/recognition of injuries and across social situations. This project will provide an interpersonal view of the trials associated with reintegration into civilian society experienced by those who have been wounded in recent military conflicts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Increased public attention on wounded veterans of the Iraq and Afghanistan wars has popularized the term "wounded warrior". "Wounded warrior" is a new and symbolic phrase that parallels a shift in the larger social context for post-9/11 wounded veterans. This dissertation examines the meaning of “wounded warrior” to understand how this phrase has come to define and shape the experiences of post-9/11 wounded veterans in various ways. Four main research questions are addressed: (1) How is “wounded warrior” defined and understood? What are its varied meanings, and for whom? (2) How do post-9/11 wounded veterans navigate their social identity as a “wounded warrior”? What factors influence their experience as a “wounded warrior”? (3) What consequences does the categorization of “wounded warrior” have on the community of post-9/11 wounded veterans? How do wounded veterans construct and maintain a collective group identity as “wounded warriors”? (4) How does visibility (of injuries) impact veteran’s identification with the “wounded warrior” construct? How does visibility affect veteran’s relationship to the larger wounded veteran community?

We use two forms of qualitative data to analyze the experiences of wounded veterans as “wounded warriors”: semi-structured in-depth interviews and a content analysis of print media coverage on wounded veterans. Qualitative research allows for an in-depth analysis of how the “wounded warrior” status is constructed and the meaning it carries in wounded veterans every day lives. In the content analysis, we analyzed a stratified sample of news articles from four different sources (the New York Times, Washington Post, USA Today, and UT San Diego) between the years of 2001 and 2015. The data from the content analysis is able to speak to broader narratives about wounded veterans, their injuries, and their experiences, capturing how the public may view “wounded warriors.” This NSF grant directly supported our collection of 39 interviews with post-9/11 wounded, injured and ill veterans. The interviews were conducted at two different cities located near major military hospitals: San Diego, California and San Antonio, Texas. Visibility of injury, whether others can readily see the injury, was the primary comparative element in the interview sample in order to deepen our understanding of variation in the “wounded warrior” experience. Over half of the sample was veterans with visible injuries ranging from amputations, burn injuries, to other deformities and visible scarring. Veterans interviewed with invisible injuries had post-traumatic stress disorder, traumatic brain injuries, chronic pain, hearing loss, and other invisible wounds. 

Wounded veterans experience their status as a “wounded warrior” as both an individual and a group identity. Veterans navigate their personal lives as a “wounded warrior”, but they also adhere to community norms and expectations to be accepted by their wounded veteran peers. The public experience of the “wounded warrior” identity is significantly shaped by the visibility of injuries; thus, the same identity comes to impact veteran’s lives in very different ways. Visibly injured veterans, especially those with commonly portrayed injuries (like amputees and burn survivors), have visible markers that convey their veteran status, allowing them to negate the stigma of physical disability. However, because their injuries are so public, they find it hard to escape the identity of being a “wounded warrior.” Invisibly injured veterans keep their veteran status hidden because they feel their veteran status will only exaggerate the stigma of their invisible wounds. The stigma attached to different kinds of wounds and its interaction with veteran status changes veteran’s relationship to their identity as a “wounded warrior”, which may prevent certain types of wounded veterans from engaging in the community or identifying themselves as wounded.

Combat wounded veterans create distinctions between themselves and other “wounded warriors” to preserve their own status as authentic “wounded warriors” and to distance themselves from being seen as disabled. The wounded veteran community experiences a disjuncture between the bureaucratic definition of who qualifies as a “wounded warrior” and the cultural symbol of “wounded warrior.” Non-combat injured veterans are, in some circumstances, considered “wounded warriors” even though the popular understanding of a “wounded warrior” is a veteran injured in combat. Wounded veterans use boundary work, internal expectations and norms, to establish and control a social hierarchy of authenticity in the community. Authentic wounded veterans are those who are wounded in combat and uphold the social expectations of empowerment and humility in their actions and attitudes. Wounded veterans who are non-combat injured or are perceived as playing the victim, acting greedy or entitled risk being isolated or rejected by authentic “wounded warriors.” Post-9/11 combat wounded veterans distinguish themselves as the most worthy kind of “wounded warrior” by using social means to reinforce and uphold their privileged position, reclaiming the meaning of their service and sacrifice.
